tasks.title: Produce competitive scan of podcast show notes tool market
subtasks: Read Thomas's requirements doc, Meeting #3 transcript, Yuki's revenue model, and competitive analysis skill reference
Researched Castmagic pricing and features via WebSearch and WebFetch — confirmed $29-999/mo subscription tiers, 5-80 hrs/mo, content repurposing suite
Researched Podium pricing via WebSearch and third-party sources — $24/mo Creator plan, $6-9/hr pay-as-you-go credits, English-only transcripts on base tier
Researched Podsqueeze pricing and features — confirmed free tier (30 min), $8.99-89.99/mo paid plans, strongest indie offering of incumbents
Researched Capsho pricing — single $99/mo tier (300 min), heavy content marketing focus, AI personas feature
Researched Descript pricing and podcast features — $0-50/mo tiers, show notes as secondary feature within editing platform
Evaluated Riverside.fm but excluded from top 5 — recording platform with show notes as add-on, different buying decision
Searched for pay-per-episode pricing models across all tools — confirmed no competitor offers clean per-episode checkout as primary model
Verified indie podcaster market data — 85% not monetizing (Podnews 2025), 619M global listeners projected 2026
Compiled 9-dimension comparison table for all 5 competitors with verified pricing from primary sources
Analyzed pricing landscape: subscription-dominant market, $20/mo threshold where indie creators drop off, free tiers as loss leaders

Identified 5 specific feature gaps: (1) no pay-per-episode workflow, (2) over-featured suites for simple use case, (3) no host-optimized markdown export, (4) SEO features gated behind expensive tiers, (5) poor link resolution from audio mentions
Wrote Go recommendation with clear rationale tied to market gap, pricing opportunity, and Yuki's unit economics validation
decisions: Selected Castmagic, Podium, Podsqueeze, Capsho, and Descript as top 5 — these are the most relevant direct competitors for AI-powered podcast show notes generation
Excluded Riverside.fm from top 5 because it's a recording platform that added show notes as a feature, not a show notes tool — different competitive category
Recommended Go based on clear market gap: no pay-per-episode tool exists, all competitors are over-featured content suites at $20+/mo, indie segment is underserved
Flagged pay-per-episode conversion as the key unvalidated assumption — recommended soft launch with both per-episode and bundle options
Flagged show notes quality as table stakes risk — if output quality isn't noticeably better than free-tier competitors, the value prop reduces to pricing alone
